flow.context: Ryan White is President of Mission Bay Vacation Rentals (legally Prevail Realty, Inc.), a 100+ property vacation rental company laser-focused on Mission Beach and Mission Bay in San Diego. He co-leads with Ryan Jantz (Owner); the company has been around since 2003. They promise 'meticulously kept accommodations' and 'minutes' response times with a high-touch local team — but have no known inspection software or PMS. A July 2025 review called a unit 'disgusting,' and San Diego's STRO licensing regime is tightening (fee changes March 2025, Tier 4 waitlist reopening July 2025). Sam connection: Sam surfs and grew up in SoCal — Mission Beach is a surf mecca, and Ryan runs the rental operation right on the beach. Easy rapport opener.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Ryan — this might be a little out of left field, but I work with a few vacation rental managers in the San Diego beach markets. I actually grew up in LA and surf Mission Beach every time I'm down — figured I should finally connect with the people who actually run that stretch. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Feet up energy. You're a SoCal surfer who knows his turf — not a telemarketer. Let the surf comment breathe, don't rush past it. If he bites on the surf angle, riff for a second before transitioning.

branches.label: What's this about? / Who are you?

heard_name_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF ME
heard_name_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is — I work with a few other property managers running 100-plus units in beach markets, and honestly something keeps coming up that I think you'd get. Mind if I take 30 seconds to tell you why I called?
heard_name_no.note: Self-deprecating laugh, then pivot to asking for time. Don't launch into pain yet — get a micro-yes first.

heard_name_yes.label: HEARD OF ME
heard_name_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
heard_name_yes.note: Let them talk. Whatever they say, bridge to: 'Yeah that's pretty much it — the reason I wanted to connect directly is...' then go to pain trigger.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow, maybe around this same time? Or would later this week be better?
bad_timing.note: Give two options. Don't ask open-ended 'when works.' Lock a specific callback or lose the lead.

branches.label: Gives a time / says call back

callback_confirmed.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
callback_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Ryan. Talk soon.
callback_confirmed.note: Put the callback in your CRM immediately. Don't sell anything else — just lock it and hang up.

whats_this_about.label: WHAT'S THIS ABOUT
whats_this_about.say: Yeah totally fair — it is a cold call, I'll own that. I work with a few vacation rental companies in the San Diego beach markets on their turnover and inspection workflows. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? You can totally hang up on me if it doesn't land.
whats_this_about.note: He's screening, not rejecting. Admitting it's a cold call disarms. Ask for 30 seconds — most people give it once you're honest.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER
gatekeeper.say: Hey — could you get me through to Ryan? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Nothing else. Don't explain, don't pitch. Let the pause do the work. Sound like you know him.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER WANTS CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property managers in the Mission Beach area. Would you mind letting him know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Dose info bit by bit. Don't pitch the gatekeeper. Keep it peer-level, not vendor-level.

branches.label: He's not available / take a message

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: We help a couple other property management companies with their inspection workflows — I sent Ryan a note and just wanted to give him a heads up. Would you mind putting me through or letting him know I called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: 'Sent a note' + 'give him a heads up' sounds like follow-up, not a cold call. End with a redirect question — you ask, you control.

gatekeeper_unavailable.label: GATEKEEPER — NOT AVAILABLE
gatekeeper_unavailable.say: No worries at all. What's the best time to catch him — mornings or afternoons? And who am I speaking with, by the way?
gatekeeper_unavailable.note: Get the gatekeeper's name for next time. Get a callback window. If they mention Dixie Jantz, note it — she's a rental agent and could be a useful internal champion.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So here's why I called. I work with another property manager — pretty similar setup to you guys, over a hundred beach rentals, high-turnover market — and the thing that kept killing them was the gap between what their cleaners said was ready and what guests actually walked into. They'd get the turnover done, photos looked fine on a quick scroll, but then a guest checks in and finds a stained couch cushion, or the BBQ's missing a grate, or a bathroom wasn't touched. Now they're issuing a refund, sending someone over in a panic, and there's a one-star review going up. With a hundred-plus units turning over in peak season in Mission Beach, that math gets ugly fast — especially now with STRO enforcement tightening up where one bad complaint could actually put a license at risk. Does any of that sound familiar, or am I totally off base?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after 'off base.' Do not keep talking. Let him react. The STRO reference is specific to San Diego — it shows you know his world. The 'stained couch, missing BBQ grate' details match their property types (beach homes, condos with patios and BBQs).

branches.label: Yeah that resonates / we deal with that
We actually have a good process

pain_positive.label: THEY FEEL THE PAIN
pain_positive.say: Yeah — I hear that from basically every manager running this volume in beach markets. Out of curiosity, what does your inspection process look like right now after turnovers? Like are your cleaners taking photos, or is someone from your team going back through units?
pain_positive.note: STOP PITCHING. They're warm — switch to discovery. You want to understand their current workflow so the solution feels like a natural fit, not a product push.

branches.label: Describes their process (photos, checklists, manual, etc.)
We don't really have a formal process

pain_neutral.label: LUKEWARM / SKEPTICAL
pain_neutral.say: Totally fair. I mean you guys have been doing this for over 20 years — I'd expect you'd have something dialed in. The thing I keep hearing though, even from operators who feel pretty locked in, is that the volume makes it hard to actually verify every unit before a guest walks in. With a hundred-plus units, are you physically inspecting every turnover, or is it more of a spot-check situation?
pain_neutral.note: Acknowledge their experience — they've been around since 2003. Then use a question to surface the gap. Nobody inspects every unit every time at 100+ scale without automation.

branches.label: We spot check / can't get to every one
We inspect every one (claims tight process)

one_sentence_solution.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
one_sentence_solution.say: We built an AI that looks at the turnover photos and videos your team is already taking and automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues — anything off. No workflow change, it just plugs into whatever you're already doing and catches the stuff that slips by a human scrolling through 50 photos on a phone screen.
one_sentence_solution.note: One breath. Don't oversell. If you know their PMS, say 'plugs into your PMS.' Since we don't know theirs, keep it generic: 'whatever you're already doing.'

branches.label: That's interesting / how does it work?

discovery_current_process.label: DISCOVERY — CURRENT PROCESS
discovery_current_process.say: Got it. So when those photos come in, who's actually reviewing them? Is it you, is it someone on the property management team, or is it kind of on the honor system with the cleaners?
discovery_current_process.note: You're mapping their workflow. Find out where the gap is — who reviews, how fast, what gets missed. This tells you who the internal champion is and what the actual pain point feels like day-to-day.

branches.label: I review / someone on the team reviews
We use a platform for it

discovery_no_process.label: DISCOVERY — NO FORMAL PROCESS
discovery_no_process.say: Yeah — that's actually really common at your scale. Most managers I talk to in the hundred-plus range either don't have time to formalize it or had a process that broke when they scaled past 50 units. That's actually the exact gap we fill. Would you be open to me showing you what it looks like — just a quick 15 minutes, not a whole sales pitch? Worst case you see what other managers in your market are doing and steal some ideas.
discovery_no_process.note: No judgment in your voice. Normalize it. Then offer value — 'see what others in your market are doing' is the hook, not a product demo.

branches.label: Yeah sure / I'd look at that

discovery_cleaners_handle.label: DISCOVERY — CLEANERS HANDLE IT
discovery_cleaners_handle.say: Makes sense — that's how most operators run it. The tricky part is the cleaners are incentivized to say it's done, right? Nobody's submitting photos of the thing they missed. So you end up finding out about problems from the guest, which is the worst time to find out. Is that something you've been running into, or has it been pretty clean?
discovery_cleaners_handle.note: Frame the conflict of interest gently — cleaners marking their own homework. Then ask if it's been an issue. The July 2025 review suggests it has, but let HIM say it.

discovery_review_burden.label: DISCOVERY — REVIEW BURDEN
discovery_review_burden.say: Gotcha. So how many turnovers are you doing in a week during peak season? And is that person looking at every single photo set, or is it more of a skim?
discovery_review_burden.note: You're quantifying the burden. At 100+ units in a beach market, peak season could be 50-80+ turnovers per week. Nobody reviews all of those thoroughly.

branches.label: Shares volume / admits it's a lot

discovery_honor_system.label: DISCOVERY — HONOR SYSTEM
discovery_honor_system.say: Yeah — and honestly that works fine most of the time. The problem is when it doesn't, right? Like the one unit out of 20 where the cleaner missed something and the guest walks in and it's a mess. Especially with how STRO enforcement has ramped up — a guest complaint that used to just be a bad review can now actually put your license in play. Has that been on your radar at all?
discovery_honor_system.note: Bridge cleaner gaps to STRO risk. This is specific to San Diego and shows you understand the regulatory environment. The Tier 4 waitlist and fee changes are real pressure.

branches.label: Yeah STRO has been on our mind
We haven't had issues with STRO
Tell me more about what you do

discovery_what_platform.label: DISCOVERY — WHAT PLATFORM
discovery_what_platform.say: Oh nice — what are you guys using?
discovery_what_platform.note: Shut up and listen. Whatever they say, note it. If it's Breezeway, Track, Streamline — we integrate. If it's manual or a generic checklist app, that's our opening. If it's a competitor, don't trash it.

branches.label: Not sure / someone else manages it

known_platform.label: THEY HAVE A PLATFORM
known_platform.say: Oh solid — that's a good tool. So when photos come in through that, is someone actually reviewing every set, or does stuff still slip through? Because what we've seen is the platform captures the photos fine, but the review step is where it falls apart at scale — nobody has time to look at every image across a hundred-plus units.
known_platform.note: Don't trash their tool. Compliment it, then reframe the gap: capture vs. review. RapidEye doesn't replace their platform — it makes the photos they're already collecting actually useful.

branches.label: We're pretty happy with what we have

stro_pressure.label: STRO REGULATORY PRESSURE
stro_pressure.say: Yeah — I've been hearing that a lot from San Diego managers. Between the fee changes that hit in March and the Tier 4 waitlist reopening next month, it feels like the city's getting more serious about enforcement. And I think the thing that scares most operators is that a guest complaint or a neighbor call — something that used to just be a bad day — can now actually threaten your license. Having documentation that the unit was guest-ready before they walked in becomes a lot more valuable in that world. Is that something you've been thinking about, or is it more of a background concern?
stro_pressure.note: STRO specifics: fee changes effective March 1, 2025; Mission Beach Tier 4 waitlist reopening July 1, 2025. This shows you know San Diego regulation — not just generic 'regulations are tough.' Let him talk.

bridge_to_solution.label: BRIDGE TO SOLUTION
bridge_to_solution.say: Yeah — so that's really why I reached out. We built a tool that looks at the photos and videos your team is already capturing during turnovers and uses AI to automatically flag anything that's off — damage, missing items, staging issues, cleanliness problems. No workflow change for your cleaners, no new hardware. It just plugs in and catches the stuff that a human scrolling on a phone at 8 AM would miss. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
bridge_to_solution.note: This is the CTA. Keep it light — 'when I'm not cold calling you' softens it. You're not asking them to buy, you're asking them to look.

branches.label: We're not looking for anything right now

warm_discovery.label: WARM — DEEP DISCOVERY
warm_discovery.say: So before I talk your ear off — what does the inspection side of things look like for you guys right now? Like after a turnover, is there a formal check before the next guest walks in, or is it more trust-based with your cleaners?
warm_discovery.note: They're engaged. Go into discovery mode. You want to understand their current workflow, pain points, and who owns the process internally. Listen more than you talk.

explain_deeper.label: EXPLAIN DEEPER
explain_deeper.say: Yeah so — think of it this way. Your cleaners or inspectors are already taking photos after a turnover, right? Those photos go somewhere — a PMS, a Google Drive, a text thread, whatever. We connect to that and our AI scans every image automatically. So if there's a stain on a couch that wasn't there last turnover, or a patio chair is missing, or the bathroom mirror is cracked — it flags it before the guest checks in. It's basically a second set of eyes on every single unit, every single turnover, without adding any work for your team.
explain_deeper.note: Use concrete examples that match their property types — beach homes, patios, BBQs. Keep it vivid and tangible, not technical.

integration_question.label: INTEGRATION QUESTION
integration_question.say: We plug into most major PMS and ops platforms — Breezeway, Track, Streamline, Guesty. If you're using something else or even just doing it manually, we can work with that too. What are you guys running on?
integration_question.note: This is a chance to learn their tech stack — it wasn't identified in research. Whatever they say, confirm we integrate or can accommodate. Don't oversell compatibility you can't deliver.

branches.label: Not sure / someone else handles that

defer_cost.label: COST QUESTION — DEFER
defer_cost.say: Yeah totally fair question. Honestly it depends on unit count and volume — I don't want to throw out a number that's wrong. That's actually part of why I'd love to just show you the platform for 15 minutes. I can give you exact pricing based on your setup and you can see if the math makes sense. Would sometime this week or next work?
defer_cost.note: Never quote price on a cold call. Defer to the meeting. Pricing depends on their setup — that's true and it's a reason to meet.

defer_cost_again.label: COST — STILL PUSHING
defer_cost_again.say: I hear you — I really don't want to give you a number that's off though. For context, most of our operators at your scale say it pays for itself within the first couple months just in avoided refunds and maintenance catches. But I'd rather show you the actual output on one of your properties so you can judge for yourself. Fair enough?
defer_cost_again.note: Anchor value to avoided costs, not product price. Then redirect to the meeting. If they keep pushing, give a range in the meeting — not on a cold call.

objection_not_interested_early.label: NOT INTERESTED — EARLY
objection_not_interested_early.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not relevant?
objection_not_interested_early.note: This is the permission fallback. They haven't heard the pitch yet — earn 30 seconds before accepting the no.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I just caught you at a horrible time, or is it more that you already know what we do and this just isn't relevant?
permission_rejected.note: Split the objection. 'Horrible time' reopens a callback. 'Already know' means they've evaluated and passed — different conversation.

objection_not_interested.label: NOT INTERESTED — POST-PITCH
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. I should have assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would have reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that this isn't really a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls and the timing is off?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise them. Then split the objection. 'Not focused on it' vs 'hate cold calls' gets you real information.

branches.label: Not a problem we're focused on
Just bad timing / hate cold calls
We're happy with what we have

objection_not_focused.label: NOT FOCUSED ON THIS
objection_not_focused.say: Makes total sense — I mean you guys have a hundred-plus units and peak season coming up, there's probably ten things ahead of this on the list. Honestly the operators who get the most out of this are the ones who looked at it before they actually needed it. Would you be open to just a quick 15 minutes so it's on your radar? If nothing else, I can walk you through what a couple other managers in the Mission Beach area are doing with their turnover workflows. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
objection_not_focused.note: Sell the test drive. Lower the stakes — 'on your radar' not 'buy now.' The 'Mission Beach area' reference shows you know competitors are doing this.

objection_timing_save.label: TIMING SAVE
objection_timing_save.say: Ha — I don't blame you. Totally respect that. Would it be a terrible idea to shoot you a quick email with what we do, and if it's interesting you can tell me to call you back at a time that doesn't suck?
objection_timing_save.note: Convert to email follow-up with a callback embedded. Don't push for a meeting if they're annoyed — email is the bridge.

objection_have_process.label: THEY HAVE A PROCESS / VENDOR
objection_have_process.say: That totally makes sense — with a hundred-plus properties you'd have to have something in place. And honestly I'd be worried if you didn't. Just so I'm not wasting your time if I follow up — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how it's working, or is it more that switching anything right now would just be a headache you don't need?
objection_have_process.note: Agree first, then split. 'Happy with it' vs 'switching is a headache' are very different objections. Most people say switching is the headache — which means the door is open.

happy_with_process.label: HAPPY WITH PROCESS
happy_with_process.say: Love that — honestly that's rare. Most managers I talk to at your scale are kind of white-knuckling it through peak season. Out of curiosity, are you using a platform for it or is it more of an internal process your team built?
happy_with_process.note: Genuine curiosity. Learn what they're using — it's intel even if this call doesn't convert. And 'white-knuckling' might get them to admit it's not as buttoned up as they said.

branches.label: Really don't want to get into it

happy_but_manual.label: HAPPY BUT MANUAL
happy_but_manual.say: Gotcha — so it's working but it's manual. The thing I hear a lot is that stuff works great at 50, 60 units, but once you're past a hundred — especially in a peak season beach market — the manual process starts to crack. Not because the people are bad, but because the volume makes it impossible to actually check everything. That's really all we do — we make the photos your team's already taking actually get reviewed, every unit, every turnover. Would you be open to just seeing it? Fifteen minutes, and if it's not for you I'll leave you alone.
happy_but_manual.note: Reframe manual as a scale problem, not a quality problem. Respect their team, challenge the physics. Then soft CTA.

switching_headache.label: SWITCHING HEADACHE
switching_headache.say: Totally get that. And honestly we're not asking you to switch anything — we layer on top of whatever you're already doing. Your cleaners don't change anything, your workflow stays the same, we just add an AI review on top of the photos they're already taking. That's actually why most of our operators say yes — because there's nothing to rip and replace. Would you be open to a quick look?
switching_headache.note: Key objection buster: RapidEye is additive, not a replacement. No workflow change. This is the strongest counter to 'switching is hard.'

objection_no_budget.label: NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that budget for this cycle is completely tapped out, or is it more that anything you try to buy right now puts you through the ringer with approvals?
objection_no_budget.note: Agree, then split. 'Tapped out' means revisit later. 'Approval ringer' means find the right person or right timing.

budget_tapped.label: BUDGET TAPPED
budget_tapped.say: Makes sense. You're probably not buying anything right now, and I totally respect that. But when budget does free up — could be next quarter, could be next season — the people who get the most value are the ones who already know what's on their list. Would you be open to just taking a look now so when the timing is right you already know if this makes sense? No commitment, just intel.
budget_tapped.note: Sell the test drive. The meeting has value independent of buying today. 'Intel' reframes the meeting as serving them, not you.

budget_approvals.label: BUDGET APPROVALS
budget_approvals.say: Gotcha. Is that something you and Ryan Jantz decide together, or is there someone else involved in tooling decisions?
budget_approvals.note: You know Ryan Jantz is the Owner. If White isn't the sole buyer, you need to understand the decision structure. This might open a path to a joint meeting.

branches.label: It's me and Ryan / we decide together

book_meeting_both.label: BOOK MEETING — BOTH RYANS
book_meeting_both.say: Perfect — would it make sense to get both of you on for 15 minutes so nobody's playing telephone? I've got next Tuesday pulled up — how does the morning look?
book_meeting_both.note: If both Ryans decide, get both on the call. Pick a specific day and time. Don't leave it open-ended.

branches.label: Let me check with him first

objection_send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
objection_send_email.say: Totally fair. One question before I do — what would be most useful to include so it's not just another generic cold email you delete? Like is it more about how it works technically, or how it plays out operationally for a company at your scale?
objection_send_email.note: Accept the email request, but ask what to include. This tells you their priority AND keeps the conversation going for 30 more seconds. Include a specific meeting time suggestion in the email.

email_confirmed.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED
email_confirmed.say: Got it — I'll keep it short and relevant. And I'll throw a couple time options in there in case you want to hop on a quick call after you read it. What's the best email — is it rwhite at missionbayvacationrentals?
email_confirmed.note: Confirm email, embed a meeting CTA in the follow-up. The inferred email is rwhite@missionbayvacationrentals.com — confirm it or get the real one.

email_ending.label: EMAIL WRAP
email_ending.say: Perfect. I'll get that over to you today. Appreciate you hearing me out, Ryan — enjoy the rest of your day.
email_ending.note: Send the email within 30 minutes. Subject line should reference the call: 'Following up from our call — RapidEye.' Include 2-3 specific meeting time options. Keep it short.

referral_ops_person.label: REFERRAL — FIND OPS PERSON
referral_ops_person.say: Totally makes sense. Who on your team typically owns the turnover and inspection side of things day to day? I'd love to put something tailored together so it actually lands with the right person.
referral_ops_person.note: Ryan White is President — he may delegate ops. Get a name and title. If they mention Dixie Jantz (Rental Agent), that's your internal champion path. If they mention a property management team lead, even better.

branches.label: That's really me / I handle it

referral_confirmed.label: REFERRAL CONFIRMED
referral_confirmed.say: Perfect — and would it be cool if I mentioned your name when I reach out to them? Just so it doesn't feel like a total cold call on their end.
referral_confirmed.note: Get permission to name-drop. This turns your next call from cold to warm. Note the name, title, and any contact info they share.

referral_ending.label: REFERRAL WRAP
referral_ending.say: Really appreciate that, Ryan. I'll reach out to them and keep it relevant. Thanks for your time — enjoy the rest of your day.
referral_ending.note: Log the referral immediately. Call the referred person within 24 hours while the conversation is fresh.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next week pulled up — would Tuesday or Wednesday work better for a quick 15 minutes? I'm flexible on time.
book_meeting.note: Pick specific days. Don't say 'when works for you' — that creates decision paralysis. Lock day first, then time. Send the invite while still on the phone if possible.

branches.label: Let me check my calendar and get back to you

meeting_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — I'll send over an invite right now so it's locked in. It'll be quick, I promise — 15 minutes, I'll show you what it looks like on a real property, and you can tell me if it makes sense for your setup. Really appreciate you taking my call, Ryan. Talk to you then.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. The meeting is booked. Send the calendar invite immediately. Include a brief agenda in the invite: 'Quick look at how RapidEye works for turnover inspections — 15 min.' Confirm with a short email after.

ending_graceful.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
ending_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything changes down the road, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Ryan. Have a good one.
ending_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Stay warm and professional. Log the outcome and set a follow-up reminder for 60-90 days. He might come around after a bad turnover or a STRO scare.
